verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:1
verses.text: The Divine Institutes Book : Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:3
verses.text: —Of the Former Religion of Men, and How Error Was Spread Over Every Age, and of the Seven Wise Men of Greece.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:4
verses.text: When I reflect, O Emperor Constantine, and often revolve in my mind the original condition of men, it is accustomed to appear alike wonderful and unworthy that, by the folly of one age embracing various superstitions, and believing in the existence of many gods, they suddenly arrived at such ignorance of themselves, that the truth being taken away from their eyes, the religion of the true God was not observed, nor the condition of human nature, since men did not seek the chief good in heaven, but on earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:5
verses.text: And on this account assuredly the happiness of the ancient ages was changed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:6
verses.text: For, having left God, the parent and founder of all things, men began to worship the senseless works of their own hands.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:7
verses.text: And what were the effects of this corruption, or what evils it introduced, the subject itself sufficiently declares.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:8
verses.text: For, turning away from the chief good, which is blessed and everlasting on this account, because it cannot be seen, or touched, or comprehended, and from the virtues which are in agreement with that good, and which are equally immortal, gliding down to these corrupt and frail gods, and devoting themselves to those things by which the body only is adorned, and nourished, and delighted, they sought eternal death for themselves, together with their gods and goods relating to the body, because all bodies are subject to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:9
verses.text: Superstitions of this kind, therefore, were followed by injustice and impiety, as must necessarily be the case.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:10
verses.text: For men ceased to raise their countenances to the heaven; but, their minds being depressed downwards, clung to goods of the earth, as they did to earth-born superstitions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:11
verses.text: There followed the disagreement of mankind, and fraud, and all wickedness; because, despising eternal and incorruptible goods, which alone ought to be desired by man, they rather chose temporal and short-lived things, and greater trust was placed by men in evil, inasmuch as they preferred vice to virtue, because it had presented itself as nearer at hand.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:12
verses.text: Thus human life, which in former ages had been occupied with the clearest light, was overspread with gloom and darkness; and in conformity with this depravity, when wisdom was taken away, then at length men began to claim for themselves the name of wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:13
verses.text: For at the time when all were wise, no one was called by that name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:14
verses.text: And would that this name, once common to all the class, though reduced to a few, still retained its power! For those few might perhaps be able, either by talent, or by authority, or by continual exhortations, to free the people from vices and errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:15
verses.text: But so entirely had wisdom died out, that it is evident, from the very arrogance of the name, that no one of those who were so called was really wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:16
verses.text: And yet, before the discovery of this philosophy, as it is termed, there are said to have been seven, who, because they ventured to inquire into and discuss natural subjects, deserved to be esteemed and called wise men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:17
verses.text: O wretched and calamitous age, in which through the whole world there were only seven who were called by the name of men, for no one can justly be called a man unless he is wise! But if all the others besides themselves were foolish, even they themselves were not wise, because no one can be truly wise in the judgment of the foolish.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:18
verses.text: So far were they removed from wisdom, that not even afterwards, when learning increased, and many and great intellects were always intent upon this very subject, could the truth be perceived and ascertained.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:19
verses.text: For, after the renown of those seven wise men, it is incredible with how great a desire of inquiring into the truth all Greece was inflamed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:20
verses.text: And first of all, they thought the very name of wisdom arrogant, and did not call themselves wise men, but desirous of wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:21
verses.text: By which deed they both condemned those who had rashly arrogated to themselves the name of wise men, of error and folly, and themselves also of ignorance, which indeed they did not deny.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:22
verses.text: For wherever the nature of the subject had, as it were, laid its hands upon their minds, so that they were unable to give any account, they were accustomed to testify that, they knew nothing, and discerned nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 1:23
verses.text: Wherefore they are found to be much wiser, who in some degree saw themselves, than those who had believed that they were wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:2
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:3
verses.text: —Where Wisdom is to Be Found; Why Pythagoras and Plato Did Not Approach the Jews.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:4
verses.text: Wherefore, if they were not wise who were so called, nor those of later times, who did not hesitate to confess their want of wisdom, what remains but that wisdom is to be sought elsewhere, since it has not been found where it was sought.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:5
verses.text: But what can we suppose to have been the reason why it was not found, though sought with the greatest earnestness and labour by so many intellects, and during so many ages, unless it be that philosophers sought for it out of their own limits? And since they traversed and explored all parts, but nowhere found any wisdom, and it must of necessity be somewhere, it is evident that it ought especially to be sought there where the title of folly appears; under the covering of which God hides the treasury of wisdom and truth, lest the secret of His divine work should be exposed to view.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:6
verses.text: Whence I am accustomed to wonder that, when Pythagoras, and after him Plato, inflamed with the love of searching out the truth, had penetrated as far as to the Egyptians, and Magi, and Persians, that they might become acquainted with their religious rites and institutions (for they suspected that wisdom was concerned with religion), they did not approach the Jews only, in whose possession alone it then was, and to whom they might have gone more easily.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:7
verses.text: But I think that they were turned away from them by divine providence, that they might not know the truth, because it was not yet permitted for the religion of the true God and righteousness to become known to men of other nations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:8
verses.text: For God had determined, as the last time drew near, to send from heaven a great leader, who should reveal to foreign nations that which was taken away from a perfidious and ungrateful people.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 2:9
verses.text: And I will endeavour to discuss the subject in this book, if I shall first have shown that wisdom is so closely united with religion, that the one cannot be separated from the other.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:2
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:3
verses.text: —Wisdom and Religion Cannot Be Separated: the Lord of Nature Must Necessarily Be the Father of Every One.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:4
verses.text: The worship of the gods, as I have taught in the former book, does not imply wisdom; not only because it gives up man, who is a divine animal, to earthly and frail things, but because nothing is fixed in it which may avail for the cultivation of the character and the framing of the life; nor does it contain any investigation of the truth, but only the rite of worship, which does not consist in the service of the mind, but in the employment of the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:5
verses.text: And therefore that is not to be deemed true religion, because it instructs and improves men by no precepts of righteousness and virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:6
verses.text: Thus philosophy, inasmuch as it does not possess true religion, that is, the highest piety, is not true wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:7
verses.text: For if the divinity which governs this world supports mankind with incredible beneficence, and cherishes it as with paternal indulgence, wishes truly that gratitude should be paid, and honour given to itself, man cannot preserve his piety if he shall prove ungrateful for the heavenly benefits; and this is certainly not the part of a wise man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:8
verses.text: Since, therefore, as I have said, philosophy and the religious system of the gods are separated, and far removed from each other; seeing that some are professors of wisdom, through whom it is manifest that there is no approach to the gods, and that others are priests of religion, through whom wisdom is not learned; it is manifest that the one is not true wisdom, and that the other is not true religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:9
verses.text: Therefore philosophy was not able to conceive the truth, nor was the religious system of the gods able to give an account of itself, since it is without it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:10
verses.text: But where wisdom is joined by an inseparable connection with religion, both must necessarily be true; because in our worship we ought to be wise, that is, to know the proper object and mode of worship, and in our wisdom to worship, that is, to complete our knowledge by deed and action.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:11
verses.text: Where, then, is wisdom joined with religion? There, indeed, where the one God is worshipped, where life and every action is referred to one source, and to one supreme authority: in short, the teachers of wisdom are the same, who are also the priests of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:12
verses.text: Nor, however, let it affect any one, because it often has happened, and may happen, that some philosopher may undertake a priesthood of the gods; and when this happens, philosophy is not, however, joined with religion; but philosophy will both be unemployed amidst sacred rites, and religion will be unemployed when philosophy shall be treated of.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:13
verses.text: For that system of religious rites is dumb, not only because it relates to gods who are dumb, but also because its observance is by the hand and the fingers, not by the heart and tongue, as is the case with ours, which is true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:14
verses.text: Therefore religion is contained in wisdom, and wisdom in religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:15
verses.text: The one, then, cannot be separated from the other; because wisdom is nothing else but the worship of the true God with just and pious adoration.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:16
verses.text: But that the worship of many gods is not in accordance with nature, may be inferred and conceived even by this argument: that every god who is worshipped by man must, amidst the solemn rites and prayers, be invoked as father, not only for the sake of honour, but also of reason; because he is both more ancient than man, and because he affords life, safety, and sustenance, as a father does.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:17
verses.text: Therefore Jupiter is called father by those who pray to him, as is Saturnus, and Janus, and Liber, and the rest in order; which Lucilius laughs at in the council of the gods: "So that there is none of us who is not called excellent father of the gods; so that father Neptunus, Liber, father Saturnus, Mars, Janus, father Quirinus, are called after one name".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:18
verses.text: But if nature does not permit that one man should have many fathers (for he is produced from one only), therefore the worship of many gods is contrary to nature, and contrary to piety.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:19
verses.text: One only, therefore, is to be worshipped, who can truly be called Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:20
verses.text: He also must of necessity be Lord, because as He has power to indulge, so also has He power to restrain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:21
verses.text: He is to be called Father on this account, because He bestows upon us many and great things; and Lord on this account, because He has the greatest power of chastising and punishing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:22
verses.text: But that He who is Father is also Lord, is shown even by reference to civil law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:23
verses.text: For who will be able to bring up sons, unless he has the power of a lord over them? Nor without reason is he called father of a household, although he only has sons: for it is plain that the name of father embraces also slaves, because "household" follows; and the name of "household" comprises also sons, because the name of "father" precedes: from which it is evident, that the same person is both father of his slaves and lord of his sons.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:24
verses.text: Lastly, the son is set at liberty as if he were a slave; and the liberated slave receives the name of his patron, as if he were a son.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:25
verses.text: But if a man is named father of a household, that it may appear that he is possessed of a double power, because as a father he ought to indulge, and as a lord to restrain, it follows that he who is a son is also a slave, and that he who is a father is also a lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:26
verses.text: As, therefore, by the necessity of nature, there cannot be more than one father, so there can only be one lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:27
verses.text: For what will the slave do if many lords shall give commands at variance with each other? Therefore the worship of many gods is contrary to reason and to nature, since there cannot be many fathers or lords; but it is necessary to consider the gods both as fathers and lords.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:28
verses.text: Therefore the truth cannot be held where the same man is subject to many fathers and lords, where the mind, drawn in different directions to many objects, wanders to and fro, hither and thither.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:29
verses.text: Nor can religion have any firmness, when it is without a fixed and settled dwelling-place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:30
verses.text: Therefore there can be no true worship of many gods; just as that cannot be called matrimony, in which one woman has many husbands, but she will either be called a harlot or an adulteress.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:31
verses.text: For when a woman is destitute of modesty, chastity, and fidelity, she must of necessity be without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 3:32
verses.text: Thus also the religious system of the gods is unchaste and unholy, because it is destitute of faith, for that unsettled and uncertain honour has no source or origin.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:2
verses.text: —Of Wisdom Likewise, and Religion, and of the Right of Father and Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:3
verses.text: By these things it is evident how closely connected are wisdom and religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:4
verses.text: Wisdom relates to sons, and this relation requires love; religion to servants, and this relation requires fear.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:5
verses.text: For as the former are bound to love and honour their father, so are the latter bound to respect and venerate their lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:6
verses.text: But with respect to God, who is one only, inasmuch as He sustains the twofold character both of Father and Lord, we are bound both to love Him, inasmuch as we are sons, and to fear Him, inasmuch as we are servants.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:7
verses.text: Religion, therefore, cannot be divided from wisdom, nor can wisdom be separated from religion; because it is the same God, who ought to be understood, which is the part of wisdom, and to be honoured, which is the part of religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:8
verses.text: But wisdom precedes, religion follows; for the knowledge of God comes first, His worship is the result of knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:9
verses.text: Thus in the two names there is but one meaning, though it seems to be different in each case.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:10
verses.text: For the one is concerned with the understanding, the other with action.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:11
verses.text: But, however, they resemble two streams flowing from one fountain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:12
verses.text: But the fountain of wisdom and religion is God; and if these two streams shall turn aside from Him, they must be dried up: for they who are ignorant of Him cannot be wise or religious.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:13
verses.text: Thus it comes to pass that philosophers, and those who worship many gods, either resemble disinherited sons or runaway slaves, because the one do not seek their father, nor the other their master.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:14
verses.text: And as they who are disinherited do not attain to the inheritance of their father, nor runaway slaves impunity, so neither will philosophers receive immortality, which is the inheritance of the heavenly kingdom, that is, the chief good, which they especially seek; nor will the worshippers of gods escape the penalty of everlasting death, which is the punishment of the true Master against those who are deserters of His majesty and name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:15
verses.text: But that God is Father and also Lord was unknown to both, to the worshippers of the gods as well as to the professors of wisdom themselves: inasmuch as they either thought that nothing at all was to be worshipped; or they approved of false religions; or, although they understood the strength and power of the Supreme God (as Plato, who says that there is one God, Creator of the world, and Marcus Tullius, who acknowledges that man has been produced by the Supreme God in an excellent condition), nevertheless they did not render the worship due to Him as to the supreme Father, which was their befitting and necessary duty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:16
verses.text: But that the gods cannot be fathers or lords, is declared not only by their multitude, as I have shown above, but also by reason: because it is not reported that man was made by gods, nor is it found that the gods themselves preceded the origin of man, since it appears that there were men on the earth before the birth of Vulcan, and Liber, and Apollo, and Jupiter himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:17
verses.text: But the creation of man is not accustomed to be assigned to Saturnus, nor to his father Coelus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:18
verses.text: But if none of those who are worshipped is said to have originally formed and created man, it follows that none of these can be called the father of man, and so none of them can be God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:19
verses.text: Therefore it is not lawful to worship those by whom man was not produced, for he could not be produced by many.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:20
verses.text: Therefore the one and only God ought to be worshipped, who was before Jupiter, and Saturnus, and Coelus himself, and the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:21
verses.text: For He must have fashioned man, who, before the creation of man, finished the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:22
verses.text: He alone is to be called Father who created us; He alone is to be considered Lord who rules, who has the true and perpetual power of life and death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 4:23
verses.text: And he who does not adore Him is a foolish servant, who flees from or does not know his Master; and an undutiful son, who either hates or is ignorant of his true Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:2
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:3
verses.text: —The Oracles of the Prophets Must Be Looked Into; And of Their Times, and the Times of the Judges and Kings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:4
verses.text: Now, since I have shown that wisdom and religion cannot be separated, it remains that we speak of religion itself, and wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:5
verses.text: I am aware, indeed, how difficult it is to discuss heavenly subjects; but still the attempt must be ventured, that the truth may be made clear and brought to light, and that many may be freed from error and death, who despise and refuse the truth, while it is concealed under a covering of folly.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:6
verses.text: But before I begin to speak of God and His works, I must first speak a few things concerning the prophets, whose testimony I must now use, which I have refrained from doing in the former books.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:7
verses.text: Above all things, he who desires to comprehend the truth ought not only to apply his mind to understand the utterances of the prophets, but also most diligently to inquire into the times during which each one of them existed, that he may know what future events they predicted, and after how many years their predictions were fulfilled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:8
verses.text: Nor is there any difficulty in making these computations; for they testified under what king each of them received the inspiration of the Divine Spirit.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:9
verses.text: And many have written and published books respecting the times, making their commencement from the prophet Moses, who lived about seven hundred years before the Trojan war.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:10
verses.text: But he, when he had governed the people for forty years, was succeeded by Joshua, who held the chief place twenty-seven years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:11
verses.text: After this they were under the government of judges during three hundred and seventy years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:12
verses.text: Then their condition was changed, and they began to have kings; and when they had ruled during four hundred and fifty years, until the reign of Zedekiah, the Jews having been besieged by the king of Babylon, and carried into captivity, endured a long servitude, until, in the seventieth year afterwards, the captive Jews were restored to their own lands and settlements by Cyrus the elder, who attained the supreme power over the Persians, at the time when Tarquinius Superbus reigned at Rome.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:13
verses.text: Wherefore, since the whole series of times may be collected both from the Jewish histories and from those of the Greeks and Romans, the times of the prophets individually may also be collected; the last of whom was Zechariah, and it is agreed on that he prophesied in the time of King Darius, in the second year of his reign, and in the eighth month.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:14
verses.text: Of so much greater antiquity are the prophets found to be than the Greek writers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:15
verses.text: And I bring forward all these things, that they may perceive their error who endeavour to refute Holy Scripture, as though it were new and recently composed, being ignorant from what fountain the origin of our holy religion flowed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 5:16
verses.text: But if any one, having put together and examined the times, shall duly lay the foundation of learning, and fully ascertain the truth, he will also lay aside his error when he has gained the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:2
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:3
verses.text: —Almighty God Begat His Son; And the Testimonies of the Sibyls and of Trismegistus Concerning Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:4
verses.text: God, therefore, the contriver and founder of all things, as we have said in the second book, before He commenced this excellent work of the world, begat a pure and incorruptible Spirit, whom He called His Son.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:5
verses.text: And although He had afterwards created by Himself innumerable other beings, whom we call angels, this first-begotten, however, was the only one whom He considered worthy of being called by the divine name, as being powerful in His Father's excellence and majesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:6
verses.text: But that there is a Son of the Most High God, who is possessed of the greatest power, is shown not only by the unanimous utterances of the prophets, but also by the declaration of Trismegistus and the predictions of the Sibyls.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:7
verses.text: Hermes, in the book which is entitled The Perfect Word, made use of these words: "The Lord and Creator of all things, whom we have thought right to call God, since He made the second God visible and sensible.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:8
verses.text: But I use the term sensible, not because He Himself perceives (for the question is not whether He Himself perceives), but because He leads to perception and to intelligence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:9
verses.text: Since, therefore, He made Him first, and alone, and one only, He appeared to Him beautiful, and most full of all good things; and He hallowed Him, and altogether loved Him as His own Son".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:10
verses.text: The Erythraean Sibyl, in the beginning of her poem, which she commenced with the Supreme God, proclaims the Son of God as the leader and commander of all, in these verses:—  "The nourisher and creator of all things, who placed the sweet breath in all, and made God the leader of all".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:11
verses.text: And again, at the end of the same poem:—  "But whom God gave for faithful men to honour".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:12
verses.text: And another Sibyl enjoins that He ought to be known:—  "Know Him as your God, who is the Son of God".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:13
verses.text: Assuredly He is the very Son of God, who by that most wise King Solomon, full of divine inspiration, spake these things which we have added:, "God founded me in the beginning of His ways, in His work before the ages.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:14
verses.text: He set me up in the beginning, before He made the earth, and before He established the depths, before the fountains of waters came forth: the Lord begat me before all the hills; He made the regions, and the uninhabitable boundaries under the heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:15
verses.text: When He prepared the heaven, I was by Him: and when He separated His own seat, when He made the strong clouds above the winds, and when He strengthened the mountains, and placed them under heaven; when He laid the strong foundations of the earth, I was with Him arranging all things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:16
verses.text: I was He in whom He delighted: I was daily delighted, when He rejoiced, the world being completed".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 6:17
verses.text: But on this account Trismegistus spoke of Him as "the artificer of God," and the Sibyl calls Him "Counsellor," because He is endowed by God the Father with such wisdom and strength, that God employed both His wisdom and hands in the creation of the world.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:2
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:3
verses.text: —Of the Name of Son, and Whence He is Called Jesus and Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:4
verses.text: Some one may perhaps ask who this is who is so powerful, so beloved by God, and what name He has, who was not only begotten at first before the world, but who also arranged it by His wisdom and constructed it by His might.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:5
verses.text: First of all, it is befitting that we should know that His name is not known even to the angels who dwell in heaven, but to Himself only, and to God the Father; nor will that name be published, as the sacred writings relate, before that the purpose of God shall be fulfilled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:6
verses.text: In the next place, we must know that this name cannot be uttered by the mouth of man, as Hermes teaches, saying these things: "Now the cause of this cause is the will of the divine good which produced God, whose name cannot be uttered by the mouth of man".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:7
verses.text: And shortly afterwards to His Son: "There is, O Son, a secret word of wisdom, holy respecting the only Lord of all things, and the God first perceived by the mind, to speak of whom is beyond the power of man".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:8
verses.text: But although His name, which the supreme Father gave Him from the beginning, is known to none but Himself, nevertheless He has one name among the angels, and another among men, since He is called Jesus among men: for Christ is not a proper name, but a title of power and dominion; for by this the Jews were accustomed to call their kings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:9
verses.text: But the meaning of this name must be set forth, on account of the error of the ignorant, who by the change of a letter are accustomed to call Him Chrestus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:10
verses.text: The Jews had before been directed to compose a sacred oil, with which those who were called to the priesthood or to the kingdom might be anointed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:11
verses.text: And as now the robe of purple is a sign of the assumption of royal dignity among the Romans, so with them the anointing with the holy oil conferred the title and power of king.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:12
verses.text: But since the ancient Greeks used the word χρίεσθαι to express the art of anointing, which they now express by ἀλείφεσθαι, as the verse of Homer shows,  "But the attendants washed, and anointed them with oil;"    on this account we call Him Christ, that is, the Anointed, who in Hebrew is called the Messias.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:13
verses.text: Hence in some Greek writings, which are badly translated from the Hebrew, the word eleimmenos is found written, from the word aleiphesthai, anointing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:14
verses.text: But, however, by either name a king is signified: not that He has obtained this earthly kingdom, the time for receiving which has not yet arrived, but that He sways a heavenly and eternal kingdom, concerning which we shall speak in the last book.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 7:15
verses.text: But now let us speak of His first nativity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:2
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:3
verses.text: —Of the Birth of Jesus in the Spirit and in the Flesh: of Spirits and the Testimonies of Prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:4
verses.text: For we especially testify that He was twice born, first in the spirit, and afterwards in the flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:5
verses.text: Whence it is thus spoken by Jeremiah: "Before I formed Thee in the womb I knew Thee".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:6
verses.text: And likewise by the same: "Who was blessed before He was born;" which was the case with no one else but Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:7
verses.text: For though He was the Son of God from the beginning, He was born again a second time according to the flesh: and this twofold birth of His has introduced great terror into the minds of men, and overspread with darkness even those who retained the mysteries of true religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:8
verses.text: But we will show this plainly and clearly, that they who love wisdom may be more easily and diligently instructed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:9
verses.text: He who hears the Son of God mentioned ought not to conceive in his mind so great impiety as to think that God begat Him by marriage and union with a woman, which none does but an animal possessed of a body, and subject to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:10
verses.text: But with whom could God unite Himself, since He is alone? or since His power was so great, that He accomplished whatever He wished, assuredly He did not require the co-operation of another for procreation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:11
verses.text: Unless by chance we shall profanely imagine, as Orpheus supposed, that God is both male and female, because otherwise He would have been unable to beget, unless He had the power of each sex, as though He could have intercourse with Himself, or without such intercourse be unable to produce.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:12
verses.text: But Hermes also was of the same opinion, when he says that He was "His own father," and "His own mother".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:13
verses.text: But if this were so, as He is called by the prophets father, so also He would be called mother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:14
verses.text: In what manner, then, did He beget Him? First of all, divine operations cannot be known or declared by any one; but nevertheless the sacred writings teach us, in which it is laid down that this Son of God is the speech, or even the reason of God, and also that the other angels are spirits of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:15
verses.text: For speech is breath sent forth with a voice signifying something.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:16
verses.text: But, however, since breath and speech are sent forth from different parts, inasmuch as breath proceeds from the nostrils, speech from the mouth, the difference between the Son of God and the other angels is great.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:17
verses.text: For they proceeded from God as silent spirits, because they were not created to teach the knowledge of God, but for His service.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:18
verses.text: But though He is Himself also a spirit, yet He proceeded from the mouth of God with voice and sound, as the Word, on this account indeed, because He was about to make use of His voice to the people; that is, because He was about to be a teacher of the knowledge of God, and of the heavenly mystery to be revealed to man: which word also God Himself first spoke, that through Him He might speak to us, and that He might reveal to us the voice and will of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:19
verses.text: With good reason, therefore, is He called the Speech and the Word of God, because God, by a certain incomprehensible energy and power of His majesty, enclosed the vocal spirit proceeding from His mouth, which he had not conceived in the womb, but in His mind, within a form which has life through its own perception and wisdom, and He also fashioned other spirits of His into angels.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:20
verses.text: Our spirits are liable to dissolution, because we are mortal: but the spirits of God both live, and are lasting, and have perception; because He Himself is immortal, and the Giver both of perception and life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:21
verses.text: Our expressions, although they are mingled with the air, and fade away, yet generally remain comprised in letters; how much more must we believe that the voice of God both remains for ever, and is accompanied with perception and power, which it has derived from God the Father, as a stream from its fountain! But if any one wonders that God could be produced from God by a putting forth of the voice and breath, if he is acquainted with the sacred utterances of the prophets he will cease to wonder.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:22
verses.text: That Solomon and his father David were most powerful kings, and also prophets, may perhaps be known even to those who have not applied themselves to the sacred writings; the one of whom, who reigned subsequently to the other, preceded the destruction of the city of Troy by one hundred and forty years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:23
verses.text: His father, the writer of sacred hymns, thus speaks in the thirty-second Psalm: "By the word of God were the heavens made firm; and all their power by the breath of His mouth".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:24
verses.text: And also again in the forty-fourth Psalm: "My heart hath given utterance to a good word; I speak of my doings towards the king;" testifying, in truth, that the works of God are known to no other than to the Son alone, who is the Word of God, and who must reign for ever.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:25
verses.text: Solomon also shows that it is the Word of God, and no other, by whose hands these works of the world were made.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:26
verses.text: "I," He says, "came forth out of the mouth of the Most High before all creatures: I caused the light that faileth not to arise in the heavens, and covered the whole earth with a cloud.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:27
verses.text: I have dwelt in the height, and my throne is in the pillar of the cloud".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:28
verses.text: John also thus taught: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:29
verses.text: The same was in the beginning with God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 8:30
verses.text: All things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:2
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:3
verses.text: —Of the Word of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:4
verses.text: But the Greeks speak of Him as the Logos, more befittingly than we do as the word, or speech: for Logos signifies both speech and reason, inasmuch as He is both the voice and the wisdom of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:5
verses.text: And of this divine speech not even the philosophers were ignorant, since Zeno represents the Logos as the arranger of the established order of things, and the framer of the universe: whom also He calls Fate, and the necessity of things, and God, and the soul of Jupiter, in accordance with the custom, indeed, by which they are wont to regard Jupiter as God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:6
verses.text: But the words are no obstacle, since the sentiment is in agreement with the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:7
verses.text: For it is the spirit of God which he named the soul of Jupiter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:8
verses.text: For Trismegistus, who by some means or other searched into almost all truth, often described the excellence and majesty of the word, as the instance before mentioned declares, in which he acknowledges that there is an ineffable and sacred speech, the relation of which exceeds the measure of man's ability.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:9
verses.text: I have spoken briefly, as I have been able, concerning the first nativity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 9:10
verses.text: Now I must more fully discuss the second, since this is the subject most controverted, that we may hold forth the light of understanding to those who desire to know the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:2
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:3
verses.text: —Of the Advent of Jesus; Of the Fortunes of the Jews, and Their Government, Until the Passion of the Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:4
verses.text: In the first place, then, men ought to know that the arrangements of the Most High God have so advanced from the beginning, that it was necessary, as the end of the world approached, that the Son of God should descend to the earth, that He might build a temple for God, and teach righteousness; but, however, not with the might of an angel or with heavenly power, but in the form of man and in the condition of a mortal, that when He had discharged the office of His ministry, He might be delivered into the hands of wicked men, and might undergo death, that, having subdued this also by His might, He might rise again, and bring to man, whose nature He had put on and represented, the hope of overcoming death, and might admit him to the rewards of immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:5
verses.text: And that no one may be ignorant of this arrangement, we will show that all things were foretold which we see fulfilled in Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:6
verses.text: Let no one believe our assertion unless I shall show that the prophets before a long series of ages published that it should come to pass at length that the Son of God should be born as a man, and perform wonderful deeds, and sow the worship of God throughout the whole earth, and at last be crucified, and on the third day rise again.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:7
verses.text: And when I shall have proved all these things by the writings of those very men who treated with violence their God who had assumed a mortal body, what else will prevent it from being manifest that true wisdom is conversant with this religion only? Now the origin of the whole mystery is to be related.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:8
verses.text: Our ancestors, who were chiefs of the Hebrews, when they were distressed by famine and want, passed over into Egypt, that they might obtain a supply of corn; and sojourning there a long time, they were oppressed with an intolerable yoke of slavery.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:9
verses.text: Then God pitied them, and led them out, and freed them from the hand of the king of the Egyptians, after four hundred and thirty years, under the leadership of Moses, through whom the law was afterwards given to them by God; and in this leading out God displayed the power of His majesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:10
verses.text: For He made His people to pass through the midst of the Red Sea, His angel going before and dividing the water, so that the people might walk over the dry land, of whom it might more truly be said (as the poet says), that "the wave, closing over him after the appearance of a mountain, stood around him".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:11
verses.text: And when he heard of this, the tyrant of the Egyptians followed with this great host of his men, and rashly entering the sea which still lay open, was destroyed, together with his whole army, by the waves returning to their place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:12
verses.text: But the Hebrews, when they had entered into the wilderness, saw many wonderful deeds.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:13
verses.text: For when they suffered thirst, a rock having been struck with a rod, a fountain of water sprung forth and refreshed the people.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:14
verses.text: And again, when they were hungry, a shower of heavenly nourishment descended.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:15
verses.text: Moreover, also, the wind brought quails into their camp, so that they were not only satisfied with heavenly bread, but also with more choice banquets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:16
verses.text: And yet, in return for these divine benefits, they did not pay honour to God; but when slavery had been now removed from them, and their thirst and hunger laid aside, they fell away into luxury, and transferred their minds to the profane rites of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:17
verses.text: For when Moses, their leader, had ascended into the mountain, and there tarried forty days, they made the head of an ox in gold, which they call Apis, that it might go before them as a standard.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:18
verses.text: With which sin and crime God was offended, and justly visited the impious and ungrateful people with severe punishments, and made them subject to the law which He had given by Moses.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:19
verses.text: But afterwards, when they had settled in a desert part of Syria, the Hebrews lost their ancient name; and since the leader of their host was Judas, they were called Jews, and the land which they inhabited Judaea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:20
verses.text: And at first, indeed, they were not subject to the dominion of Kings, but civil Judges presided over the people and the law: they were not, however, appointed only for a year, as the Roman consuls, but supported by a perpetual jurisdiction.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:21
verses.text: Then, the name of Judges being taken away, the kingly power was introduced.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:22
verses.text: But during the government of the Judges the people had often undertaken corrupt religious rites; and God, offended by them, as often brought them into bondage to strangers, until again, softened by the repentance of the people, He freed them from bondage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:23
verses.text: Likewise under the Kings, being oppressed by wars with their neighbours on account of their iniquities, and at last taken captive and led to Babylon, they suffered punishment for their impiety by oppressive slavery, until Cyrus came to the kingdom, who immediately restored the Jews by an edict.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:24
verses.text: Afterwards they had tetrarchs until the time of Herod, who was in the reign of Tiberius Caesar; in whose fifteenth year, in the consulship of the two Gemini, on the d of March, the Jews crucified Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:25
verses.text: This series of events, this order, is contained in the secrets of the sacred writings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 10:26
verses.text: But I will first show for what reason Christ came to the earth, that the foundation and the system of divine religion may be manifest.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:2
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:3
verses.text: —Of the Cause of the Incarnation of Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:4
verses.text: When the Jews often resisted wholesome precepts, and departed from the divine law, going astray to the impious worship of false gods, then God filled just and chosen men with the Holy Spirit, appointing them as prophets in the midst of the people, by whom He might rebuke with threatening words the sins of the ungrateful people, and nevertheless exhort them to repent of their wickedness; for unless they did this, and, laying aside their vanities, return to their God, it would come to pass that He would change His covenant, that is, bestow the inheritance of eternal life upon foreign nations, and collect to Himself a more faithful people out of those who were aliens by birth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:5
verses.text: But they, when rebuked by the prophets, not only rejected their words; but being offended because they were upbraided for their sins, they slew the prophets themselves with studied tortures: all which things are sealed up and preserved in the sacred writings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:6
verses.text: For the prophet Jeremiah says: "I sent to you my servants the prophets; I sent them before the morning light; but ye did not hearken, nor incline your ears to hear, when I spake unto you: let every one of you turn from his evil way, and from your most corrupt affections; and ye shall dwell in the land which I gave to you and to your fathers for ever.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:7
verses.text: Walk ye not after strange gods, to serve them; and provoke me not to anger with the works of your hands, that I should destroy you".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:8
verses.text: The prophet Ezra also, who was in the times of the same Cyrus by whom the Jews were restored, thus speaks: "They rebelled against Thee, and cast Thy law behind their backs, and slew Thy prophets which testified against them, that they might turn unto Thee".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:9
verses.text: The prophet Elias also, in the third book of Kings: "I have been very jealous for the Lord God of hosts, because the children of Israel have forsaken Thee, thrown down Thine altars, and slain Thy prophets with the sword; and I only am left, and they seek my life to take it away".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:10
verses.text: On account of these impieties of theirs He cast them off for ever; and so He ceased to send to them prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:11
verses.text: But He commanded His own Son, the first-begotten, the maker of all things, His own counsellor, to descend from heaven, that He might transfer the sacred religion of God to the Gentiles, that is, to those who were ignorant of God, and might teach them righteousness, which the perfidious people had cast aside.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:12
verses.text: And He had long before threatened that He would do this, as the prophet Malachi shows, saying: "I have no pleasure in you, saith the Lord, and I will not accept an offering from your hands; for from the rising of the sun even unto its setting, my name shall be great among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:13
verses.text: David also in the seventeenth Psalm says: "Thou wilt make me the head of the heathen; a people whom I have not known shall serve me".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:14
verses.text: Isaiah also thus speaks: "I come to gather all nations and tongues; and they shall come and see my glory; and I will send among them a sign, and I will send those that escape of them unto the nations which are afar off, which have not heard my fame; and they shall declare my glory among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:15
verses.text: Therefore, when God wished to send to the earth one who should measure His temple, He was unwilling to send him with heavenly power and glory, that the people who had been ungrateful towards God might be led into the greatest error, and suffer punishment for their crimes, since they had not received their Lord and God, as the prophets had before foretold that it would thus happen.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:16
verses.text: For Isaiah whom the Jews most cruelly slew, cutting him asunder with a saw, thus speaks: "Hear, O heaven; and give ear, O earth: for the Lord hath spoken, I have begotten sons, and lifted them up on high, and they have rejected me.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:17
verses.text: The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's stall; but Israel hath not known, my people has not understood".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:18
verses.text: Jeremiah also says, in like manner: "The turtle and the swallow hath known her time, and the sparrows of the field have observed the times of their coming: but my people have not known the judgment of the Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:19
verses.text: How do you say, We are wise, and the law of the Lord is with us? The meting out is in vain; the scribes are deceived and confounded: the wise men are dismayed and taken, for they have rejected the word of the Lord".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:20
verses.text: Therefore (as I had begun to say), when God had determined to send to men a teacher of righteousness, He commanded Him to be born again a second time in the flesh, and to be made in the likeness of man himself, to whom he was about to be a guide, and companion, and teacher.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:21
verses.text: But since God is kind and merciful to His people, He sent Him to those very persons whom He hated, that He might not close the way of salvation against them for ever, but might give them a free opportunity of following God, that they might both gain the reward of life if they should follow Him (which many of them do, and have done), and that they might incur the penalty of death by their fault if they should reject their King.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 11:22
verses.text: He ordered Him therefore to be born again among them, and of their seed, lest, if He should be born of another nation, they might be able to allege a just excuse from the law for their rejection of Him; and at the same time, that there might be no nation at all under heaven to which the hope of immortality should be denied.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:2
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:3
verses.text: —Of the Birth of Jesus from the Virgin; Of His Life, Death, and Resurrection, and the Testimonies of the Prophets Respecting These Things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:4
verses.text: Therefore the Holy Spirit of God, descending from heaven, chose the holy Virgin, that He might enter into her womb.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:5
verses.text: But she, being filled by the possession of the Divine Spirit, conceived; and without any intercourse with a man, her virgin womb was suddenly impregned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:6
verses.text: But if it is known to all that certain animals are accustomed to conceive by the wind and the breeze, why should any one think it wonderful when we say that a virgin was made fruitful by the Spirit of God, to whom whatever He may wish is easy? And this might have appeared incredible, had not the prophets many ages previously foretold its occurrence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:7
verses.text: Thus Solomon speaks: "The womb of a virgin was strengthened, and conceived; and a virgin was made fruitful, and became a mother in great pity".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:8
verses.text: Likewise the prophet Isaiah, whose words are these: "Therefore God Himself shall give you a sign: Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son; and ye shall call His name Emmanuel".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:9
verses.text: What can be more manifest than this? This was read by the Jews, who denied Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:10
verses.text: If any one thinks that these things are invented by us, let him inquire of them, let him take especially from them: the testimony is sufficiently strong to prove the truth, when it is alleged by enemies themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:11
verses.text: But He was never called Emmanuel, but Jesus, who in Latin is called Saving, or Saviour, because He comes bringing salvation to all nations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:12
verses.text: But by this name the prophet declared that God incarnate was about to come to men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:13
verses.text: For Emmanuel signifies God with us; because when He was born of a virgin, men ought to confess that God was with them, that is, on the earth and in mortal flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:14
verses.text: Whence David says in the eighty-fourth Psalm, "Truth has sprung out of the earth;" because God, in whom is truth, hath taken a body of earth, that He might open a way of salvation to those of the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:15
verses.text: In like manner Isaiah also: "But they disbelieved, and vexed His Holy Spirit; and He was turned to be their enemy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:16
verses.text: And He Himself fought against them, and He remembered the days of old, who raised up from the earth a shepherd of the sheep".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:17
verses.text: But who this shepherd was about to be, he declared in another place, saying: "Let the heavens rejoice, and let the clouds put on righteousness; let the earth open, and put forth a Saviour.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:18
verses.text: For I the Lord have begotten Him".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:19
verses.text: But the Saviour is, as we have said before, Jesus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:20
verses.text: But in another place the same prophet also thus proclaimed: "Behold, unto us a child is born, unto us a Son is given, whose dominion is upon His shoulders, and His name is called Messenger of great counsel".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:21
verses.text: For on this account He was sent by God the Father, that He might reveal to all the nations which are under heaven the sacred mystery of the only true God, which was taken away from the perfidious people, who ofttimes sinned against God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:22
verses.text: Daniel also foretold similar things: "I saw," he said, "in a vision of the night, and, behold, one like the Son of man coming with the clouds of heaven, and He came even to the Ancient of days.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:23
verses.text: And they who stood by brought Him near before Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:24
verses.text: And there was given unto Him a kingdom, and glory, and dominion; and all people, tribes, and languages shall serve Him: and His dominion is everlasting, which shall never pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:25
verses.text: How then do the Jews both confess and expect the Christ of God? who rejected Him on this account, because He was born of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:26
verses.text: For since it is so arranged by God that the same Christ should twice come to the earth, once to announce to the nations the one God, then again to reign, why do they who did not believe in His first advent believe in the second?  But the prophet comprises both His advents in few words.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:27
verses.text: Behold, he says, one like the Son of man coming with the clouds of heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:28
verses.text: He did not say, like the Son of God, but the Son of man, that he might show that He had to be clothed with flesh on the earth, that having assumed the form of a man and the condition of mortality, He might teach men righteousness; and when, having completed the commands of God, He had revealed the truth to the nations, He might also suffer death, that He might overcome and lay open the other world also, and thus at length rising again, He might proceed to His Father borne aloft on a cloud.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:29
verses.text: For the prophet said in addition: And came even to the Ancient of days, and was presented to Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:30
verses.text: He called the Most High God the Ancient of days, whose age and origin cannot be comprehended; for He alone was from generations, and He will be always to generations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:31
verses.text: But that Christ, after His passion and resurrection, was about to ascend to God the Father, David bore witness in these words in the cixth Psalm: "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou at my right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:32
verses.text: Whom could this prophet, being himself a king, call his Lord, who sat at the right hand of God, but Christ the Son of God, who is King of kings and Lord of lords? And this is more plainly shown by Isaiah, when he says: "Thus saith the Lord God to my Lord Christ, whose right hand I have holden; I will subdue nations before Him, and will break the strength of kings.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:33
verses.text: I will open before Him gates, and the cities shall not be closed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:34
verses.text: I will go before Thee, and will make the mountains level; and I will break in pieces the gates of brass, and shatter the bars of iron; and I will give Thee the hidden and invisible treasures, that Thou mayest know that I am the Lord God, which call Thee by Thy name, the God of Israel".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:35
verses.text: Lastly, on account of the goodness and faithfulness which He displayed towards God on earth, there was given to Him a kingdom, and glory, and dominion; and all people, tribes, and languages shall serve Him; and His dominion is everlasting, and that which shall never pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:36
verses.text: And this is understood in two ways: that even now He has an everlasting dominion, when all nations and all languages adore His name, confess His majesty, follow His teaching, and imitate His goodness: He has power and glory, in that all tribes of the earth obey His precepts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:37
verses.text: And also, when He shall come again with majesty and glory to judge every soul, and to restore the righteous to life, then He shall truly have the government of the whole earth: then, every evil having been removed from the affairs of men, a golden age (as the poets call it), that is, a time of righteousness and peace, will arise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 12:38
verses.text: But we will speak of these things more fully in the last book, when we shall speak of His second advent; now let us treat of His first advent, as we began.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:2
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:3
verses.text: —Of Jesus, God and Man; And the Testimonies of the Prophets Concerning Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:4
verses.text: Therefore the Most High God, and Parent of all, when He had purposed to transfer His religion, sent from heaven a teacher of righteousness, that in Him or through Him He might give a new law to new worshippers; not as He had before done, by the instrumentality of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:5
verses.text: Nevertheless it was His pleasure that He should be born as a man, that in all things He might be like His supreme Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:6
verses.text: For God the Father Himself, who is the origin and source of all things, inasmuch as He is without parents, is most truly named by Trismegistus "fatherless" and "motherless," because He was born from no one.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:7
verses.text: For which reason it was befitting that the Son also should be twice born, that He also might become "fatherless" and "motherless".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:8
verses.text: For in His first nativity, which was spiritual, He was "motherless," because He was begotten by God the Father alone, without the office of a mother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:9
verses.text: But in His second, which was in the flesh, He was born of a virgin's womb without the office of a father, that, bearing a middle substance between God and man, He might be able, as it were, to take by the hand this frail and weak nature of ours, and raise it to immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:10
verses.text: He became both the Son of God through the Spirit, and the Son of man through the flesh,—that is, both God and man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:11
verses.text: The power of God was displayed in Him, from the works which He performed; the frailty of the man, from the passion which He endured: on what account He undertook it I will mention a little later.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:12
verses.text: In the meantime, we learn from the predictions of the prophets that He was both God and man—composed of both natures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:13
verses.text: Isaiah testifies that He was God in these words: "Egypt is wearied, and the merchandise of Ethiopia, and the Sabaeans, men of stature, shall come over unto Thee, and shall be Thy servants: and they shall walk behind Thee; in chains they shall fall down unto Thee, and shall make supplication unto Thee, Since God is in Thee, and there is no other God besides Thee.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:14
verses.text: For Thou art God, and we knew Thee not, the God of Israel, the Saviour.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:15
verses.text: They shall all be confounded and ashamed who oppose Thee, and shall fall into confusion".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:16
verses.text: In like manner the prophet Jeremiah thus speaks: "This is our God, and there shall none other be compared unto Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:17
verses.text: He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob His servant, and to Israel His beloved.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:18
verses.text: Afterward He was seen upon earth, and dwelt among men".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:19
verses.text: David also, in the forty-fourth Psalm: "Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever; a sceptre of righteousness is the sceptre of Thy kingdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:20
verses.text: Thou hast loved righteousness, and hated wickedness; therefore God, Thy God, hath anointed Thee with the oil of gladness".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:21
verses.text: By which word he also shows His name, since (as I have shown above) He was called Christ from His anointing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:22
verses.text: Then, that He was also man, Jeremiah teaches, saying: "And He is a man, and who hath known Him?" Also Isaiah: "And God shall send to them a man, who shall save them, shall save them by judging".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:23
verses.text: But Moses also, in Numbers, thus speaks: "There shall arise a star out of Jacob, and a man shall spring forth from Israel".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:24
verses.text: On which account the Milesian Apollo, being asked whether He was God or man, replied in this manner: "He was mortal as to His body, being wise with wondrous works; but being taken with arms under Chaldean judges, with nails and the cross He endured a bitter end".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:25
verses.text: In the first verse he spoke the truth, but he skilfully deceived him who asked the question, who was entirely ignorant of the mystery of the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:26
verses.text: For he appears to have denied that He was God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:27
verses.text: But when he acknowledges that He was mortal as to the flesh, which we also declare, it follows that as to the spirit He was God, which we affirm.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:28
verses.text: For why would it have been necessary to make mention of the flesh, since it was sufficient to say that He was mortal? But being pressed by the truth, he could not deny the real state of the case; as that which he says, that He was wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:29
verses.text: What do you reply to this, Apollo? If he is wise, then his system of instruction is wisdom, and no other; and they are wise who follow it, and no others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:30
verses.text: Why then are we commonly esteemed as foolish, and visionary, and senseless, who follow a Master who is wise even by the confession of the gods themselves? For in that he said that He wrought wonderful deeds, by which He especially claimed faith is His divinity, he now appears to assent to us, when he says the same things in which we boast.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:31
verses.text: But, however, he recovers himself, and again has recourse to demoniacal frauds.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:32
verses.text: For when he had been compelled to speak the truth, he now appeared to be a betrayer of the gods and of himself, unless he had, by a deceptive falsehood, concealed that which the truth had extorted from him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:33
verses.text: He says, therefore, that He did indeed perform wonderful works, yet not by divine power, but by magic.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:34
verses.text: What wonder if Apollo thus persuaded men ignorant of the truth, when the Jews also, worshippers (as they seemed to be) of the Most High God, entertained the same opinion, though they had every day before their eyes those miracles which the prophets had foretold to them as about to happen, and yet they could not be induced by the contemplation of such powers to believe that He whom they saw was God? On this account, David, whom they especially read above the other prophets, in the twenty-seventh Psalm thus condemns them: "Render to them their desert, because they regard not the works of the Lord".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:35
verses.text: Both David himself and other prophets announced that of the house of this very David, Christ should be born according to the flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:36
verses.text: Thus it is written in Isaiah: "And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, and He who shall arise to rule over the nations, in Him shall the Gentiles trust; and His rest shall be glorious".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:37
verses.text: And in another place: "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a blossom shall grow out of his root; and the Spirit of God shall rest upon Him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and of might, the spirit of knowledge and of piety; and He shall be filled with the spirit of fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:38
verses.text: Now Jesse was the father of David, from whose root he foretold that a blossom would arise; namely him of whom the Sibyl speaks, "A pure blossom shall spring forth".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:39
verses.text: Also in the second book of Kings, the prophet Nathan was sent to David, who wished to build a temple for God; and this was the word of the Lord to Nathan, saying: "Go and tell my servant David, Thus saith the Lord Almighty, Thou shall not build me a house for me to dwell in; but when thy days be fulfilled, and thou shalt sleep with thy fathers, I will raise up thy seed after thee, and I will establish His kingdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:40
verses.text: He shall build me a house for my name, and I will set up His throne for ever; and I will be to Him for a father, and He shall be to me for a son; and His house shall be established, and His kingdom for ever".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:41
verses.text: But the reason why the Jews did not understand these things was this, because Solomon the son of David built a temple for God, and the city which he called from his own name, Jerusalem.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:42
verses.text: Therefore they referred the predictions of the prophets to him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:43
verses.text: Now Solomon received the government of the kingdom from his father himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:44
verses.text: But the prophets spoke of Him who was then born after that David had slept with his fathers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:45
verses.text: Besides, the reign of Solomon was not everlasting; for he reigned forty years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:46
verses.text: In the next place, Solomon was never called the son of God, but the son of David; and the house which he built was not firmly established, as the Church, which is the true temple of God, which does not consist of walls, but of the heart and faith of the men who believe on Him, and are called faithful.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:47
verses.text: But that temple of Solomon, inasmuch as it was built by the hand, fell by the hand.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 13:48
verses.text: Lastly, his father, in the cxxvith Psalm, prophesied in this manner respecting the works of his son: "Except the Lord build the house, they have laboured in vain that built it; except the Lord keep the city, the watchman hath waked but in vain".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:2
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:3
verses.text: —Of the Priesthood of Jesus Foretold by the Prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:4
verses.text: From which things it is evident that all the prophets declared concerning Christ, that it should come to pass at some time, that being born with a body of the race of David, He should build an eternal temple in honour of God, which is called the Church, and assemble all nations to the true worship of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:5
verses.text: This is the faithful house, this is the everlasting temple; and if any one hath not sacrificed in this, he will not have the reward of immortality.
