verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:6
verses.text: And since Christ was the builder of this great and eternal temple, He must also have an everlasting priesthood in it; and there can be no approach to the shrine of the temple, and to the sight of God, except through Him who built the temple.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:7
verses.text: David in the cixth Psalm teaches the same, saying: "Before the morning-star I begat Thee.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:8
verses.text: The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent; Thou art a priest for ever, after the order of Melchisedec".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:9
verses.text: Also in the first book of Kings: "And I will raise me up a faithful Priest, who shall do all things that are in mine heart; and I will build him a sure house; and he shall walk in my sight all his days".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:10
verses.text: But who this was about to be, to whom God promised an everlasting priesthood, Zechariah most plainly teaches, even mentioning His name: "And the Lord God showed me Jesus the great Priest standing before the face of the angel of the Lord, and the adversary was standing at His right hand to resist Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:11
verses.text: And the Lord said unto the adversary, The Lord who hath chosen Jerusalem rebuke thee; and lo, a brand plucked out of the fire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:12
verses.text: And Jesus was clothed with filthy garments, and He was standing before the face of the angel.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:13
verses.text: And He answered and spake unto those that stood around before His face, saying, Take away the filthy garments from Him, and clothe Him with a flowing garment, and place a fair mitre upon His head; and they clothed Him with a garment, and placed a fair mitre upon His head.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:14
verses.text: And the angel of the Lord stood, and protested, saying to Jesus: Thus saith the Lord of hosts, If Thou wilt walk in my ways, and keep my precepts, Thou shalt judge my house, and I will give Thee those that may walk with Thee in the midst of these that stand by.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:15
verses.text: Hear, therefore, O Jesus, Thou great Priest".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:16
verses.text: Who, therefore, would not believe that the Jews were then deprived of understanding, who, when they read and heard these things, laid impious hands upon their God? But from the time in which Zechariah lived, until the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, in which Christ was crucified, nearly five hundred years are reckoned; since he flourished in the time of Darius and Alexander, who lived not long after the banishment of Tarquinius Superbus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:17
verses.text: But they were again misled and deceived in the same manner, in supposing that these things were spoken concerning Jesus the son of Nave, who was the successor of Moses, or concerning Jesus the high priest the son of Josedech; to whom none of those things which the prophet related was suited.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:18
verses.text: For they were never clothed in filthy garments, since one of them was a most powerful prince, and the other high priest; or suffered any adversity, so that they should be regarded as a brand plucked from the fire: not did they ever stand in the presence of God and the angels; nor did the prophet speak of the past so much as of the future.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:19
verses.text: He spoke, therefore, of Jesus the Son of God, to show that He would first come in humility and in the flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:20
verses.text: For this is the filthy garment, that He might prepare a temple for God, and might be scorched as a brand with fire—that is, might endure tortures from men, and at last be extinguished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:21
verses.text: For a half-burnt brand drawn forth from the hearth and extinguished, is commonly so called.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:22
verses.text: But in what manner and with what commands He was sent by God to the earth, the Spirit of God declared through the prophet, teaching us that when He had faithfully and uniformly fulfilled the will of His supreme Father, He should receive judgment and an everlasting dominion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:23
verses.text: If, He says, Thou wilt walk in my ways, and keep my precepts, then Thou shalt judge my house.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:24
verses.text: What these ways of God were, and what His precepts, is neither doubtful nor obscure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:25
verses.text: For God, when He saw that wickedness and the worship of false gods had so prevailed throughout the world, that His name had now also been taken away from the memory of men (since even the Jews, who alone had been entrusted with the secret of God, had deserted the living God, and, ensnared by the deceits of demons, had gone astray, and turned aside to the worship of images, and when rebuked by the prophets did not choose to return to God), He sent His Son as an ambassador to men, that He might turn them from their impious and vain worship to the knowledge and worship of the true God; and also that He might turn their minds from foolishness to wisdom, and from wickedness to deeds of righteousness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:26
verses.text: These are the ways of God, in which He enjoined Him to walk.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:27
verses.text: These are the precepts which He ordered to be observed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:28
verses.text: But He exhibited faith towards God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:29
verses.text: For He taught that there is but one God, and that He alone ought to be worshipped.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:30
verses.text: Nor did He at any time say that He Himself was God; for He would not have maintained His faithfulness, if, when sent to abolish the false gods, and to assert the existence of the one God, He had introduced another besides that one.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:31
verses.text: This would have been not to proclaim one God, nor to do the work of Him who sent Him, but to discharge a peculiar office for Himself, and to separate Himself from Him whom He came to reveal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 14:32
verses.text: On which account, because He was so faithful, because He arrogated nothing at all to Himself, that He might fulfil the commands of Him who sent Him, He received the dignity of everlasting Priest, and the honour of supreme King, and the authority of Judge, and the name of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:2
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:3
verses.text: —Of the Life and Miracles of Jesus, and Testimonies Concerning Them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:4
verses.text: Having spoken of the second nativity, in which, He showed Himself in the flesh to men, let us come to those wonderful works, on account of which, though they were signs of heavenly power, the Jews esteemed Him a magician.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:5
verses.text: When He first began to reach maturity He was baptized by the prophet John in the river Jordan, that He might wash away in the spiritual laver not His own sins, for it is evident that He had none, but those of the flesh, which He bare; that as He saved the Jews by undergoing circumcision, so He might save the Gentiles also by baptism—that is, by the pouring forth of the purifying dew.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:6
verses.text: Then a voice from heaven was heard: "Thou art my Son, to-day have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:7
verses.text: Which voice is found to have been foretold by David.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:8
verses.text: And the Spirit of God descended upon Him, formed after the appearance of a white dove.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:9
verses.text: From that time He began to perform the greatest miracles, not by magical tricks, which display nothing true and substantial, but by heavenly strength and power, which were foretold even long ago by the prophets who announced Him; which works are so many, that a single book is not sufficient to comprise them all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:10
verses.text: I will therefore enumerate them briefly and generally, without any designation of persons and places, that I may be able to come to the setting forth of His passion and cross, to which my discourse has long been hastening.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:11
verses.text: His powers were those which Apollo called wonderful: that wherever He journeyed, by a single word, and in a single moment, He healed the sick and infirm, and those afflicted with every kind of disease: so that those who were deprived of the use of all their limbs, having suddenly received power, were strengthened, and themselves carried their couches, on which they had a little time before been carried.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:12
verses.text: But to the lame, and to those afflicted with some defect of the feet, He not only gave the power of walking, but also of running.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:13
verses.text: Then, also, if any had their eyes blinded in the deepest darkness, He restored them to their former sight.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:14
verses.text: He also loosened the tongues of the dumb, so that they discoursed and spake eloquently.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:15
verses.text: He also opened the ears of the deaf, and caused them to hear; He cleansed the polluted and the blemished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:16
verses.text: And He performed all these things not by His hands, or the application of any remedy, but by His word and command, as also the Sibyl had foretold: "Doing all things by His word, and healing every disease".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:17
verses.text: Nor, indeed, is it wonderful that He did wonderful things by His word, since He Himself was the Word of God, relying upon heavenly strength and power.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:18
verses.text: Nor was it enough that He gave strength to the feeble, soundness of body to the maimed, health to the sick and languishing, unless He also raised the dead, as it were unbound from sleep, and recalled them to life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:19
verses.text: And the Jews, then, when they saw these things, contended that they were done by demoniacal power, although it was contained in their secret writings that all things should thus come to pass as they did.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:20
verses.text: They read indeed the words of other prophets, and of Isaiah, saying: "Be strong, ye hands that are relaxed; and ye weak knees, be comforted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:21
verses.text: Ye who are of a fearful heart, fear not, be not afraid: our Lord shall execute judgment; He Himself shall come and save us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:22
verses.text: Then shall the eyes of the blind be opened, and the ears of the deaf shall hear: then shall the lame man leap as a deer, and the tongue of the dumb speak plainly: for in the wilderness water hath broken forth, and a stream in the thirsty land".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:23
verses.text: But the Sibyl also foretold the same things in these verses:—  "And there shall be a rising again of the dead; and the course of the lame shall be swift, and the deaf shall hear, and the blind shall see, the dumb shall speak".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:24
verses.text: On account of these powers and divine works wrought by Him when a great multitude followed Him of the maimed, or sick, or of those who desired to present their sick to be healed, He went up into a desert mountain to pray there.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:25
verses.text: And when He had tarried there three days, and the people were suffering from hunger, He called His disciples, and asked what quantity of food they had with them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:26
verses.text: But they said that they had five loaves and two fishes in a wallet.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:27
verses.text: Then He commanded that these should be brought forward, and that the multitude, distributed by fifties, should recline on the ground.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:28
verses.text: When the disciples did this, He Himself broke the bread in pieces, and divided the flesh of the fishes, and in His hands both of them were increased.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:29
verses.text: And when He had ordered the disciples to set them before the people, five thousand men were satisfied, and moreover twelve baskets were filled from the fragments which remained.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:30
verses.text: What can be more wonderful, either in narration or in action? But the Sibyl had before foretold that it would take place, whose verses are related to this effect:—  "With five loaves at the same time, and with two fishes,  He shall satisfy five thousand men in the wilderness;  And afterwards taking all the fragments that remain,  He shall fill twelve baskets to the hope of many".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:31
verses.text: I ask, therefore, what the art of magic could have contrived in this case, the skill of which is of avail for nothing else than for deceiving the eyes? He also, when He was about to retire to a mountain, as He was wont, for the sake of prayer, directed His disciples to take a small ship and go before Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:32
verses.text: But they, setting out when evening was now coming on, began to be distressed through a contrary wind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:33
verses.text: And when they were now in the midst of the sea, then, setting His feet on the sea, He came up to them, walking as though on the solid ground, not as the poets fable Orion walking on the sea, who, while a part of his body was sunk in the water,  "With his shoulder rises above the waves".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:34
verses.text: And again, when He had gone to sleep in the ship, and the wind had begun to rage, even to the extremity of danger, being aroused from sleep, He immediately ordered the wind to be silent; and the waves, which were borne with great violence, were still, and immediately at His word there followed a calm.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:35
verses.text: But perhaps the sacred writings speak falsely, when they teach that there was such power in Him, that by His command He compelled the winds to obey, the seas to serve Him, diseases to depart, the dead to be submissive.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:36
verses.text: Why should I say that the Sibyls before taught the same things in their verses? one of whom, already mentioned, thus speaks:—  "He shall still the winds by His word, and calm the sea  As it rages, treading with feet of peace and in faith".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:37
verses.text: And again another, which says:—  "He shall walk on the waves, He shall release men from disease.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:38
verses.text: He shall raise the dead, and drive away many pains;  And from the bread of one wallet there shall be a satisfying of men".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:39
verses.text: Some, refuted by these testimonies, are accustomed to have recourse to the assertion that these poems were not by the Sibyls, but made up and composed by our own writers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:40
verses.text: But he will assuredly not think this who has read Cicero, and Varro, and other ancient writers, who make mention of the Erythraean and the other Sibyls, from whose books we bring forward these examples; and these authors died before the birth of Christ according to the flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:41
verses.text: But I do not doubt that these poems were in former times regarded as ravings, since no one then understood them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:42
verses.text: For they announced some marvellous wonders, of which neither the manner, nor the time, nor the author was signified.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:43
verses.text: Lastly, the Erythraean Sibyl says that it would come to pass that she would be called mad and deceitful.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:44
verses.text: But assuredly  "They will say that the Sibyl  Is mad, and deceitful: but when all things shall come to pass,  Then ye will remember me; and no one will any longer  Say that I, the prophetess of the great God, am mad".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:45
verses.text: Therefore they were neglected for many ages; but they received attention after the nativity and passion of Christ had revealed secret things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:46
verses.text: Thus it was also with the utterances of the prophets, which were read by the people of the Jews for fifteen hundred years and more, but yet were not understood until after Christ had explained them both by His word and by His works.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 15:47
verses.text: For the prophets spoke of Him; nor could the things which they said have been in any way understood, unless they had been altogether fulfilled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:2
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:3
verses.text: —Of the Passion of Jesus Christ; That It Was Foretold.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:4
verses.text: I come now to the passion itself, which is often cast in our teeth as a reproach: that we worship a man, and one who was visited and tormented with remarkable punishment: that I may show that this very passion was undergone by Him in accordance with a great and divine plan, and that goodness and truth and wisdom are contained in it alone.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:5
verses.text: For if He had been most happy on the earth, and had reigned through all His life in the greatest prosperity, no wise man would either have believed Him to be a God, or judged Him worthy of divine honour: which is the case with those who are destitute of true divinity, who not only look up to perishable riches, and frail power, and the advantages arising from the benefit of another, but even consecrate them, and knowingly do service to the memory of the dead, worshipping fortune when it is now extinguished, which the wise never regarded as an object of worship even when alive and present with them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:6
verses.text: For nothing among earthly things can be venerable and worthy of heaven; but it is virtue alone, and justice alone, which can be judged a true, and heavenly, and perpetual good, because it is neither given to any one, nor taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:7
verses.text: And since Christ came upon earth, supplied with virtue and righteousness, yea rather, since He Himself is virtue, and Himself righteousness, He descended that He might teach it and mould the character of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:8
verses.text: And having performed this office and embassy from God, on account of this very virtue which He at once taught and practised, He deserved, and was able, to be believed a God by all nations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:9
verses.text: Therefore, when a great multitude from time to time flocked to Him, either on account of the righteousness which He taught or on account of the miracles which He worked, and heard His precepts, and believed that He was sent by God, and that He was the Son of God, then the rulers and priests of the Jews, excited with anger because they were rebuked by Him as sinners, and perverted by envy, because, while the multitude flocked to Him, they saw themselves despised and deserted, and (that which was the crowning point of their guilt) blinded by folly and error, and unmindful of the instructors sent from heaven, and of the prophets, they caballed against Him, and conceived the impious design of putting Him to death, and torturing Him: of which the prophets had long before written.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:10
verses.text: For both David, in the beginning of his Psalms, foreseeing in spirit what a crime they were about to commit, says, "Blessed is the man who hath not walked in the way of the ungodly; "and Solomon in the book of Wisdom used these words: "Let us defraud the righteous, for he is unpleasant to us, and upbraideth us with our offences against the law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:11
verses.text: He maketh his boast that he has the knowledge of God; and he calleth himself the Son of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:12
verses.text: He is made to reprove our thoughts: it grieveth us even to look upon him: for his life is not like the life of others; his ways are of another fashion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:13
verses.text: We are counted by him as triflers, he withdraweth himself from our ways as from filthiness; he commendeth greatly the latter end of the just, and boasteth that he has God for his Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:14
verses.text: Let us see, therefore, if his words be true; let us prove what end he shall have; let us examine him with rebukes and torments that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience; let us condemn him to a shameful death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:15
verses.text: Such things have they imagined, and have gone astray.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:16
verses.text: For their own folly hath blinded them, and they do not understand the mysteries of God".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:17
verses.text: Does he not describe that impious design entered into by the wicked against God, so that he clearly appears to have been present? But from Solomon, who foretold these things, to the time of their accomplishment, ten hundred and ten years intervened.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:18
verses.text: We feign nothing; we add nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:19
verses.text: They who performed the actions had these accounts; they, against whom these things were spoken, read them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:20
verses.text: But even now the inheritors of their name and guilt have these accounts, and in their daily readings re-echo their own condemnation as foretold by the voice of the prophets; nor do they ever admit them into their heart, which is also itself a part of their condemnation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:21
verses.text: The Jews, therefore, being often reproved by Christ, who upbraided them with their sins and iniquities, and being almost deserted by the people, were stirred up to put Him to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:22
verses.text: Now His humility emboldened them to this deed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:23
verses.text: For when they read with what great power and glory the Son of God was about to descend from heaven, but on the other hand saw Jesus humble, peaceful, of low condition, without comeliness, they did not believe that He was the Son of God, being ignorant that two advents on His part were foretold by the prophets: the first, obscure in humility of the flesh; the other, manifest in the power of His majesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:24
verses.text: Of the first David thus speaks in the seventy-first Psalm: "He shall descend as rain upon a fleece; and in His days shall righteousness spring forth, and abundance of peace, as long as the moon is lifted up".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:25
verses.text: For as rain, if it descends upon a fleece, cannot be perceived, because it makes no sound; so he said that Christ would come to the earth without exciting the notice of any, that He might teach righteousness and peace.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:26
verses.text: Isaiah also thus spoke: "Lord, who hath believed our report? and to whom is the arm of the Lord revealed? We made proclamation before Him as children, and as a root in a thirsty land: He has no form nor glory; and we saw Him, and He had no form nor comeliness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:27
verses.text: But His form was without honour, and defective beyond the rest of men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:28
verses.text: He is a man acquainted with grief, and knowing how to endure infirmity, because He turned His face away from us; and He was not esteemed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:29
verses.text: He carries our sins, and He endures pain for us: and we thought that He Himself was in pain, and grief, and vexation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:30
verses.text: But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our offences; the chastisement of our peace was upon Him, by His bruises we are healed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:31
verses.text: All we like sheep have gone astray, and God hath delivered Him up for our sins".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:32
verses.text: And in the same manner the Sibyl spoke: "Though an object of pity, dishonoured, without form, He will give hope to those who are objects of pity".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 16:33
verses.text: On account of this humility they did not recognise their God, and entered into the detestable design of depriving Him of life, who had come to give them life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:2
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:3
verses.text: —Of the Superstitions of the Jews, and Their Hatred Against Jesus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:4
verses.text: But they alleged other causes for their anger and envy, which they bore shut up within in their hearts—namely, that He destroyed the obligation of the law given by Moses; that is, that He did not rest on the Sabbath, but laboured for the good of men; that He abolished circumcision; that He took away the necessity of abstaining from the flesh of swine;—in which things the mysteries of the Jewish religion consist.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:5
verses.text: On this account, therefore, the rest of the people, who had not yet withdrawn to Christ, were incited by the priests to regard Him as impious, because He destroyed the obligation of the law of God, though He did this not by His own judgment, but according to the will of God, and after the predictions of the prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:6
verses.text: For Micah announced that He would give a new law, in these terms: "The law shall go forth of Zion, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:7
verses.text: And He shall judge among many people, and rebuke strong nations".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:8
verses.text: For the former law, which was given by Moses, was not given on Mount Zion, but on Mount Horeb; and the Sibyl shows that it would come to pass that this law would be destroyed by the Son of God:—  "But when all these things which I told you shall be accomplished, then all the law is fulfilled with respect to Him".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:9
verses.text: But even Moses himself, by whom the law was given which they so tenaciously maintain, though they have fallen away from God, and have not acknowledged God, had foretold that it would come to pass that a very great prophet would be sent by God, who should be above the law, and be a bearer of the will of God to men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:10
verses.text: In Deuteronomy he thus left it written: "And the Lord said unto me, I will raise them up a Prophet from among their brethren, like unto thee; and I will put my word in His mouth, and He shall speak unto them all that I shall command Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:11
verses.text: And whosoever will not hearken to those things which that Prophet shall speak in my name, I will require it of him".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:12
verses.text: The Lord evidently announced by the law-giver himself that He was about to send His own Son—that is, a law alive, and present in person, and destroy that old law given by a mortal, that by Him who was eternal He might ratify afresh a law which was eternal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:13
verses.text: In like manner, Isaiah thus prophesied concerning the abolition of circumcision: "Thus saith the Lord to the men of Judah who dwell at Jerusalem, Break up your fallow ground, and sow not among thorns.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:14
verses.text: Circumcise yourselves to the Lord your God, and take away the foreskins of your heart, lest my fury come forth like fire, and burn that none can quench it".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:15
verses.text: Also Moses himself says: "In the last days the Lord shall circumcise thine heart to love the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:16
verses.text: Also Jesus the son of Nun, his successor, said: "And the Lord said unto Jesus, Make thee knives of flint very sharp, and sit and circumcise the children of Israel the second time".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:17
verses.text: He said that this second circumcision would be not of the flesh, as the first was, which the Jews practice even now, but of the heart and spirit, which was delivered by Christ, who was the true Jesus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:18
verses.text: For the prophet does not say, "And the Lord said unto me," but "unto Jesus," that he might show that God was not speaking of him, but of Christ, to whom God was then speaking.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:19
verses.text: For that Jesus represented Christ: for when he was at first called Auses, Moses, foreseeing the future, ordered that he should be called Jesus; that since he had been chosen as the leader of the warfare against Amalek, who was the enemy of the children of Israel, he might both subdue the adversary by the emblem of the name, and lead the people into the land of promise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:20
verses.text: And for this reason he was also successor to Moses, to show that the new law given by Christ Jesus was about to succeed to the old law which was given by Moses.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:21
verses.text: For that circumcision of the flesh is plainly irrational; since, if God had so willed it, He might so have formed man from the beginning, that he should be without a foreskin.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:22
verses.text: But it was a figure of this second circumcision, signifying that the breast is to be laid bare; that is, that we ought to live with an open and simple heart, since that part of the body which is circumcised has a kind of resemblance to the heart, and is to be treated with reverence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:23
verses.text: On this account God ordered that it should be laid bare, that by this argument He might admonish us not to have our breast hidden in obscurity; that is, not to veil any shameful deed within the secrets of conscience.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:24
verses.text: This is the circumcision of the heart of which the prophets speak, which God transferred from the mortal flesh to the soul, which alone is about to endure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:25
verses.text: For being desirous of promoting our life and salvation in accordance with His own goodness, in that circumcision He hath set before us repentance, that if we lay open our hearts,—that is if we confess our sins and make satisfaction to God,—we shall obtain pardon, which is denied to those who are obstinate and conceal their faults, by Him who regards not the outward appearance, as man does, but the innermost secrets of the heart.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:26
verses.text: The forbidding of the flesh of swine also has the same intention; for when God commanded them to abstain from this, He willed that this should be especially understood, that they should abstain from sins and impurities.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:27
verses.text: For this animal is filthy and unclean, and never looks up to heaven, but prostrates itself to the earth with its whole body and face: it is always the slave of its appetite and food; nor during its life can it afford any other service, as the other animals do, which either afford a vehicle for riding, or aid in the cultivation of the fields, or draw waggons by their neck, or carry burthens on their back, or furnish a covering with their skins, or abound with a supply of milk, or keep watch for guarding our houses.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:28
verses.text: Therefore He forbade them to use the flesh of the pig for food, that is, not to imitate the life of swine, which are nourished only for death; lest, by devoting themselves to their appetite and pleasures, they should be useless for working righteousness, and should be visited with death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:29
verses.text: Also that they should not immerse themselves in foul lusts, as the sow, which wallows in the mire; of that they do not serve earthly images, and thus defile themselves with mud: for they do bedaub themselves with mud who worship gods, that is, who worship mud and earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 17:30
verses.text: Thus all the precepts of the Jewish law have for their object the setting forth of righteousness, since they are given in a mysterious manner, that under the figure of carnal things those which are spiritual might be known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:2
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:3
verses.text: —Of the Lord's Passion, and that It Was Foretold.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:4
verses.text: When, therefore, Christ fulfilled these things which God would have done, and which He foretold many ages before by His prophets, incited by these things, and ignorant of the sacred Scriptures, they conspired together to condemn their God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:5
verses.text: And though He knew that this would come to pass, and repeatedly said that He must suffer and be put to death for the salvation of many, nevertheless He withdrew Himself with His disciples, not that He might avoid that which it was necessary for Him to undergo and endure, but that He might show what ought to take place in every persecution, that no one should appear to have fallen into it through his own fault: and He announced that it would come to pass that He should be betrayed by one of them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:6
verses.text: And thus Judas, induced by a bribe, delivered up to the Jews the Son of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:7
verses.text: But they took and brought Him before Pontius Pilate, who at that time was administering the province of Syria as governor, and demanded that He should be crucified, though they laid nothing else to His charge except that He said that He was the Son of God, the King of the Jews; also His own saying, "Destroy this temple, which was forty-six years in building, and in three days I will raise it up again without hands,"—signifying that His passion would shortly take place, and that He, having been put to death by the Jews, would rise again on the third day.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:8
verses.text: For He Himself was the true temple of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:9
verses.text: They inveighed against these expressions of His, as ill-omened and impious.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:10
verses.text: And when Pilate had heard these things, and He said nothing in His own defence, he gave sentence that there appeared nothing deserving of condemnation in Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:11
verses.text: But those most unjust accusers, together with the people whom they had stirred up, began to cry out, and with loud voices to demand His crucifixion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:12
verses.text: Then Pontius was overpowered both by their outcries, and by the instigation of Herod the tetrarch, who feared lest he should be deposed from his sovereignty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:13
verses.text: He did not, however, himself pass sentence, but delivered Him up to the Jews, that they themselves might judge Him according to their law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:14
verses.text: Therefore they led Him away when He had been scourged with rods, and before they crucified Him they mocked Him; for they put upon Him a scarlet robe, and a crown of thorns, and saluted Him as King, and gave Him gall for food, and mingled for Him vinegar to drink.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:15
verses.text: After these things they spat upon His face, and struck Him with the palms of their hands; and when the executioners themselves contended about His garments, they cast lots among themselves for His tunic and mantle.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:16
verses.text: And while all these things were doing, He uttered no voice from His mouth, as though He were dumb.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:17
verses.text: Then they lifted Him up in the midst between two malefactors, who had been condemned for robbery, and fixed Him to the cross.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:18
verses.text: What can I here deplore in so great a crime? or in what words can I lament such great wickedness? For we are not relating the crucifixion of Gavius, which Marcus Tullius followed up with all the spirit and strength of his eloquence, pouring forth as it were the fountains of all his genius, proclaiming that it was an unworthy deed that a Roman citizen should be crucified in violation of all laws.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:19
verses.text: And although He was innocent, and undeserving of that punishment, yet He was put to death, and that, too, by an impious man, who was ignorant of justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:20
verses.text: What shall I say respecting the indignity of this cross, on which the Son of God was suspended and nailed? Who will be found so eloquent, and supplied with so great an abundance of deeds and words, what speech flowing with such copious exuberance, as to lament in a befitting manner that cross, which the world itself, and all the elements of the world, bewailed?  But that these things were thus about to happen, was announced both by the utterances of the prophets and by the predictions of the Sibyls.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:21
verses.text: In Isaiah it is found thus written: "I am not rebellious, nor do I oppose: I gave my back to the scourge, and my cheeks to the hand: I turned not away my face from the foulness of spitting".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:22
verses.text: In like manner David, in the thirty-fourth Psalm: "The abjects were gathered together against me, and they knew me not: they were dispersed, nor did they feel remorse; they tempted me, and greatly derided me; and they gnashed upon me with their teeth".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:23
verses.text: The Sibyl also showed that the same things would happen:—  "He shall afterwards come into the hands of the unjust and the faithless; and they shall inflict on God blows with impure hands, and with polluted mouths they shall send forth poisonous spittle; and He shall then absolutely give His holy back to stripes".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:24
verses.text: Likewise respecting His silence, which He perseveringly maintained even to His death, Isaiah thus spoke again: "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and as a lamb before the shearer is dumb, so He opened not His mouth".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:25
verses.text: And the above-mentioned Sibyl said:—  "And being beaten, He shall be silent, lest any one should know what the Word is, or whence it came, that it may speak with mortals; and He shall wear the crown of thorns".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:26
verses.text: But respecting the food and the drink which they offered to Him before they fastened Him to the cross, David thus speaks in the sixty-eighth Psalm: "And they gave me gall for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:27
verses.text: The Sibyl foretold that this also would happen:—  "They gave me gall for my food, and for my thirst vinegar; this inhospitable table they will show".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:28
verses.text: And another Sibyl rebukes the land of Judaea in these verses:—  "For you, entertaining hurtful thoughts, did not recognise your God sporting with mortal thoughts; but crowned Him with a crown of thorns, and mingled dreadful gall".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:29
verses.text: Now, that it would come to pass that the Jews would lay hands upon their God, and put Him to death, these testimonies of the prophets foretold.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:30
verses.text: In Esdras it is thus written: "And Ezra said to the people, This passover is our Saviour and our refuge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:31
verses.text: Consider and let it come into your heart, that we have to abase Him in a figure; and after these things we will hope in Him, lest this place be deserted for ever, saith the Lord God of hosts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:32
verses.text: If you will not believe Him, nor hear His announcement, ye shall be a derision among the nations".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:33
verses.text: From which it appears that the Jews had no other hope, unless they purified themselves from blood, and put their hopes in that very person whom they denied.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:34
verses.text: Isaiah also points out their deed, and says: "In His humiliation His judgment was taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:35
verses.text: Who shall declare His generation? for His life shall be taken away from the earth; from the transgressions of my people He was led away to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:36
verses.text: And I will give Him the wicked for His burial, and the rich for His death, because He did no wickedness, nor spoke guile with His mouth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:37
verses.text: Wherefore He shall obtain many, and shall divide the spoils of the strong; because He was delivered up to death, and was reckoned among the transgressors; and He bore the sins of many, and was delivered up on account of their transgressions".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:38
verses.text: David also, in the ninety-third Psalm: "They will hunt after the soul of the righteous, and condemn the innocent blood; and the Lord is become my refuge".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:39
verses.text: Also Jeremiah: "Lord, declare it unto me, and I shall know.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:40
verses.text: Then I saw their devices; I was led as an innocent lamb to the sacrifice; they meditated a plan against me, saying, Come, let us send wood into his bread, and let us sweep away his life from the earth, and his name shall no more be remembered".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:41
verses.text: Now the wood signifies the cross, and the bread His body; for He Himself is the food and the life of all who believe in the flesh which He bare, and on the cross upon which He was suspended.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:42
verses.text: Respecting this, however, Moses himself more plainly spoke to this effect, in Deuteronomy: "And Thy life shall hang before Thine eyes; and Thou shall fear day and night, and shalt have no assurance of Thy life".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:43
verses.text: And the same again in Numbers: "God is not in doubt as a man, nor does He suffer threats as the son of man".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:44
verses.text: Zechariah also thus wrote: "And they shall look on me, whom they pierced".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:45
verses.text: Also David in the twenty-first Psalm: "They pierced my hands and my feet; they numbered all my bones; they themselves looked and stared upon me; they divided my garments among them; and upon my vesture they did cast lots".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:46
verses.text: It is evident that the prophet did not speak these things concerning himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:47
verses.text: For he was a king, and never endured these sufferings; but the Spirit of God, who was about to suffer these things, after ten hundred and fifty years, spoke by him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:48
verses.text: For this is the number of years from the reign of David to the crucifixion of Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 18:49
verses.text: But Solomon also, his son, who built Jerusalem, prophesied that this very city would perish in revenge for the sacred cross: "But if ye turn away from me, saith the Lord, and will not keep my truth, I will drive Israel from the land which I have given them; and this house which I have built for them in my name, I will cast it out from all: and Israel shall be for perdition and a reproach to the people; and this house shall be desolate, and every one that shall pass by it shall be astonished, and shall say, Why hath God done these evils to this land and to this house? And they shall say, Because they forsook the Lord their God, and persecuted their King most beloved by God, and crucified Him with great degradation, therefore hath God brought upon them these evils".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:2
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:3
verses.text: —Of the Death, Burial, and Resurrection of Jesus; And the Predictions of These Events.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:4
verses.text: What more can now be said respecting the crime of the Jews, than that they were then blinded and seized with incurable madness, who read these things daily, and yet neither understood them, nor were able to be on their guard so as not to do them? Therefore, being lifted up and nailed to the cross, He cried to the Lord with a loud voice, and of His own accord gave up His spirit.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:5
verses.text: And at the same hour there was an earthquake; and the veil of the temple, which separated the two tabernacles, was rent into two parts; and the sun suddenly withdrew its light, and there was darkness from the sixth even to the ninth hour.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:6
verses.text: Of which event the prophet Amos testifies: "And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord, that the sun shall go down at noon, and the daylight shall be darkened; and I will turn your feasts into mourning, and your songs into lamentation".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:7
verses.text: Also Jeremiah: "She who brings forth is affrighted, and vexed in spirit; her sun is gone down while it was yet mid-day; she hath been ashamed and confounded; and the residue of them will I give to the sword in the sight of their enemies".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:8
verses.text: And the Sibyl:—  "And the veil of the temple shall be rent, and at midday there shall be dark vast night for three hours,"    When these things were done, even by the heavenly prodigies, they were not able to understand their crime.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:9
verses.text: But since He had foretold that on the third day He should rise again from the dead, fearing lest, the body having been stolen by the disciples, and removed, all should believe that He had risen, and there should be a much greater disturbance among the people, they took Him down from the cross, and having shut Him up in a tomb, they securely surrounded it with a guard of soldiers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:10
verses.text: But on the third day, before light, there was an earthquake, and the sepulchre was suddenly opened; and the guard, who were astonished and stupefied with fear, seeing nothing, He came forth uninjured and alive from the sepulchre, and went into Galilee to seek His disciples: but nothing was found in the sepulchre except the grave-clothes in which they had enclosed and wrapt His body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:11
verses.text: Now, that He would not remain in hell, but rise again on the third day, had been foretold by the prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:12
verses.text: David says, in the fifteenth Psalm: "Thou wilt not leave my soul in hell; neither wilt Thou suffer Thine holy one to see corruption".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:13
verses.text: Also in the third Psalm: "I laid me down to sleep, and took my rest, and rose again, for the Lord sustained me".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:14
verses.text: Hosea also, the first of the twelve prophets, testified of His resurrection: "This my Son is wise, therefore He will not remain in the anguish of His sons: and I will redeem Him from the power of the grave.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:15
verses.text: Where is thy judgment, O death? or where is thy sting?" The same also in another place: "After two days, He will revive us in the third day".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:16
verses.text: And therefore the Sibyl said, that after three days' sleep he would put an end to death:—  "And after sleeping three days, He shall put an end to the fate of death; and then, releasing Himself from the dead, He shall come to light, first showing to the called ones the beginning of the resurrection".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:17
verses.text: For He gained life for us by overcoming death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 19:18
verses.text: No hope, therefore, of gaining immortality is given to man, unless he shall believe on Him, and shall take up that cross to be borne and endured.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:2
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:3
verses.text: —Of the Departure of Jesus into Galilee After His Resurrection; And of the Two Testaments, the Old and the New.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:4
verses.text: Therefore He went into Galilee, for He was unwilling to show Himself to the Jews, lest He should lead them to repentance, and restore them from their impiety to a sound mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:5
verses.text: And there He opened to His disciples again assembled the writings of Holy Scripture, that is, the secrets of the prophets; which before His suffering could by no means be understood, for they told of Him and of His passion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:6
verses.text: Therefore Moses, and the prophets also themselves, call the law which was given to the Jews a testament: for unless the testator shall have died, a testament cannot be confirmed; nor can that which is written in it be known, because it is closed and sealed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:7
verses.text: And thus, unless Christ had undergone death, the testament could not have been opened; that is, the mystery of God could not have been unveiled and understood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:8
verses.text: But all Scripture is divided into two Testaments.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:9
verses.text: That which preceded the advent and passion of Christ—that is, the law and the prophets—is called the Old; but those things which were written after His resurrection are named the New Testament.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:10
verses.text: The Jews make use of the Old, we of the New: but yet they are not discordant, for the New is the fulfilling of the Old, and in both there is the same testator, even Christ, who, having suffered death for us, made us heirs of His everlasting kingdom, the people of the Jews being deprived and disinherited.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:11
verses.text: As the prophet Jeremiah testifies when he speaks such things: "Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new testament to the house of Israel and the house of Judah, not according to the testament which I made to their fathers, in the day that I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt; for they continued not in my testament, and I disregarded them, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:12
verses.text: Also in another place he says in like manner: "I have forsaken my house, I have given up mine heritage into the hand of its enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:13
verses.text: Mine heritage is become unto me as a lion in the forest; it hath cried out against me, therefore have I hated it".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:14
verses.text: Since the inheritance is His heavenly kingdom, it is evident that He does not say that He hates the inheritance itself, but the heirs, who have been ungrateful towards Him, and impious.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:15
verses.text: Mine heritage, he says, is become unto me as a lion; that is, I am become a prey and a devouring to my heirs, who have slain me as the flock.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:16
verses.text: It hath cried out against me; that is, they have pronounced against me the sentence of death and the cross.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:17
verses.text: For that which He said above, that He would make a new testament to the house of Judah, shows that the old testament which was given by Moses was not perfect; but that that which was to be given by Christ would be complete.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:18
verses.text: But it is plain that the house of Judah does not signify the Jews, whom He casts off, but us, who have been called by Him out of the Gentiles, and have by adoption succeeded to their place, and are called sons of the Jews, which the Sibyl declares when she says:—  "The divine race of the blessed, heavenly Jews".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:19
verses.text: But what that race was about to be, Isaiah teaches, in whose book the Most High Father addresses His Son: "I the Lord God have called Thee in righteousness, and will hold Thine hand, and will keep Thee: and I have given Thee for a covenant of my race, for a light of the Gentiles; to open the eyes of the blind, to bring out the prisoners from the prison, and them that sit in darkness out of the prison-house".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 20:20
verses.text: When, therefore, we who were in time past as it were blind, and as it were shut up in the prison of folly, were sitting in darkness, ignorant of God and of the truth, we have been enlightened by Him, who adopted us by His testament; and having freed us from cruel chains, and brought us out to the light of wisdom, He admitted us to the inheritance of His heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:2
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:3
verses.text: —Of the Ascension of Jesus, and the Foretelling of It; And of the Preaching and Actions of the Disciples.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:4
verses.text: But when He had made arrangements with His disciples for the preaching of the Gospel and His name, a cloud suddenly surrounded Him, and carried Him up into heaven, on the fortieth day after His passion, as Daniel had shown that it would be, saying: "And, behold, one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:5
verses.text: But the disciples, being dispersed through the provinces, everywhere laid the foundations of the Church, themselves also in the name of their divine Master doing many and almost incredible miracles; for at His departure He had endowed them with power and strength, by which the system of their new announcement might be founded and confirmed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:6
verses.text: But He also opened to them all things which were about to happen, which Peter and Paul preached at Rome; and this preaching being written for the sake of remembrance, became permanent, in which they both declared other wonderful things, and also said that it was about to come to pass, that after a short time God would send against them a king who would subdue the Jews, and level their cities to the ground, and besiege the people themselves, worn out with hunger and thirst.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:7
verses.text: Then it should come to pass that they should feed on the bodies of their own children, and consume one another.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:8
verses.text: Lastly, that they should be taken captive, and come into the hands of their enemies, and should see their wives most cruelly harassed before their eyes, their virgins ravished and polluted, their sons torn in pieces, their little ones dashed to the ground; and lastly, everything laid waste with fire and sword, the captives banished for ever from their own lands, because they had exulted over the well-beloved and most approved Son of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 21:9
verses.text: And so, after their decease, when Nero had put them to death, Vespasian destroyed the name and nation of the Jews, and did all things which they had foretold as about to come to pass.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:2
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:3
verses.text: —Arguments of Unbelievers Against the Incarnation of Jesus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:4
verses.text: I have now confirmed, as I imagine, the things which are thought false and incredible by those who are not instructed in the true knowledge of heavenly learning.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:5
verses.text: But, however, that we may refute those also who are too wise, not without injury to themselves, and who detract from the credit due to divine things, let us disprove their error, that they may at length perceive that the fact ought to have been as we show that it actually was.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:6
verses.text: And although with good judges either testimonies are of sufficient weight without arguments, or arguments without testimonies, we, however, are not content with the one or the other, since we are supplied with both, that we may not leave room for any one of depraved ingenuity either to misunderstand or to dispute on the opposite side.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:7
verses.text: They say that it was impossible for anything to be withdrawn from an immortal nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:8
verses.text: They say, in short, that it was unworthy of God to be willing to become man, and to burthen Himself with the infirmity of flesh; to become subject of His own accord to sufferings, to pain, and death: as though it had not been easy for Him to show Himself to men without the weakness incident to a body, and to teach them righteousness (if He so wished) with greater authority, as of one who acknowledged Himself to be God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:9
verses.text: For in that case all would have obeyed the heavenly precepts, if the influence and power of God enjoining them had been united with them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:10
verses.text: Why, then (they say), did He not come as God to teach men? why did He render Himself so humble and weak, that it was possible for Him both to be despised by men and to be visited with punishment? why did He suffer violence from those who are weak and mortal? why did He not repel by strength, or avoid by His divine knowledge, the hands of men? why did He not at least in His very death reveal His majesty? but He was led as one without strength to trial, was condemned as one who was guilty, was put to death as one who was mortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:11
verses.text: I will carefully refute these things, nor will I permit any one to be in error.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 22:12
verses.text: For these things were done by a great and wonderful plan; and he who shall understand this, will not only cease to wonder that God was tortured by men, but also will easily see that it could not have been believed that he was God if those very things which he censures had not been done.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:2
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:3
verses.text: —Of Giving Precepts, and Acting.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:4
verses.text: If any one gives to men precepts for living, and moulds the characters of others, I ask whether he is bound himself to practice the things which he enjoins, or is not bound.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:5
verses.text: If he shall not do so, his precepts are annulled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:6
verses.text: For if the things which are enjoined are good, if they place the life of men in the best condition, the instructor ought not to separate himself from the number and assemblage of men among whom he acts; and he ought himself to live in the same manner in which he teaches that men ought to live, lest, by living in another way, he himself should disparage his own precepts, and make his instruction of less value, if in reality he should relax the obligations of that which he endeavours to establish by his words.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:7
verses.text: For every one, when he hears another giving precepts, is unwilling that the necessity of obeying should be imposed upon him, as though the right of liberty were taken from him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:8
verses.text: Therefore he answers his teacher in this manner: I am not able to do the things which you command, for they are impossible.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:9
verses.text: For you forbid me to be angry, you forbid me to covet, you forbid me to be excited by desire, you forbid me to fear pain or death; but this is so contrary to nature, that all animals are subject to these affections.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:10
verses.text: Or if you are so entirely of opinion that it is possible to resist nature, do you yourself practice the things which you enjoin, that I may know that they are possible? But since you yourself do not practice them, what arrogance is it, to wish to impose upon a free man laws which you yourself do not obey! You who teach, first learn; and before you correct the character of others, correct your own.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:11
verses.text: Who could deny the justice of this answer? Nay! a teacher of this kind will fall into contempt, and will in his turn be mocked, because he also will appear to mock others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:12
verses.text: What, therefore, will that instructor do, if these things shall be objected to him? how will he deprive the self-willed of an excuse, unless he teach them by deeds before their eyes that he teaches things which are possible? Whence it comes to pass, that no one obeys the precepts of the philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:13
verses.text: For men prefer examples rather than words, because it is easy to speak, but difficult to accomplish.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:14
verses.text: Would to heaven that there were as many who acted well as there are who speak well! But they who give precepts, without carrying them out into action, are distrusted; and if they shall be men, will be despised as inconsistent: if it shall be God, He will be met with the excuse of the frailty of man's nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:15
verses.text: It remains that words should be confirmed by deeds, which the philosophers are unable to do.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:16
verses.text: Therefore, since the instructors themselves are overcome by the affections which they say that it is our duty to overcome, they are able to train no one to virtue, which they falsely proclaim; and for this cause they imagine that no perfect wise man has as yet existed, that is, in whom the greatest virtue and perfect justice were in harmony with the greatest learning and knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:17
verses.text: And this indeed was true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 23:18
verses.text: For no one since the creation of the world has been such, except Christ, who both delivered wisdom by His word, and confirmed His teaching by presenting virtue to the eyes of men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:2
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:3
verses.text: —The Overthrowing of the Arguments Above Urged by Way of Objection.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:4
verses.text: Come, let us now consider whether a teacher sent from heaven can fail to be perfect.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:5
verses.text: I do not as yet speak of Him whom they deny to have come from God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:6
verses.text: Let us suppose that some one were to be sent from heaven to instruct the life of men in the first principles of virtue, and to form them to righteousness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:7
verses.text: No one can doubt but that this teacher, who is sent from heaven, would be as perfect in the knowledge of all things as in virtue, lest there should be no difference between a heavenly and an earthly teacher.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:8
verses.text: For in the case of a man his instruction can by no means be from within and of himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:9
verses.text: For the mind, shut in by earthly organs, and hindered by a corrupt body, of itself can neither comprehend nor receive the truth, unless it is taught from another source.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:10
verses.text: And if it had this power in the greatest degree, yet it would be unable to attain to the highest virtue, and to resist all vices, the materials of which are contained in our bodily organs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:11
verses.text: Hence it comes to pass, that an earthly teacher cannot be perfect.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:12
verses.text: But a teacher from heaven, to whom His divine nature gives knowledge, and His immortality gives virtue, must of necessity in His teaching also, as in other things, be perfect and complete.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:13
verses.text: But this cannot by any means happen, unless He should take to Himself a mortal body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:14
verses.text: And the reason why it cannot happen is manifest.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:15
verses.text: For if He should come to men as God, not to mention that mortal eyes cannot look upon and endure the glory of His majesty in His own person, assuredly God will not be able to teach virtue; for, inasmuch as He is without a body, He will not practice the things which He will teach, and through this His teaching will not be perfect.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:16
verses.text: Otherwise, if it is the greatest virtue patiently to endure pain for the sake of righteousness and duty, if it is virtue not to fear death itself when threatened, and when inflicted to undergo it with fortitude; it follows that the perfect teacher ought both to teach these things by precept, and to confirm them by practice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:17
verses.text: For he who gives precepts for the life, ought to remove every method of excuse, that he may impose upon men the necessity of obedience, not by any constraint, but by a sense of shame, and yet may leave them liberty, that a reward may be appointed for those who obey, because it was in their power not to obey if they so wished; and a punishment for those who do not obey, because it was in their power to obey if they so wished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:18
verses.text: How then can excuse be removed, unless the teacher should practice what he teaches, and as it were go before and hold out his hand to one who is about to follow? But how can one practice what he teaches, unless he is like him whom he teaches? For if he be subject to no passion, a man may thus answer him who is the teacher: It is my wish not to sin, but I am overpowered; for I am clothed with frail and weak flesh: it is this which covets, which is angry, which fears pain and death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:19
verses.text: And thus I am led on against my will; and I sin, not because it is my wish, but because I am compelled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:20
verses.text: I myself perceive that I sin; but the necessity imposed by my frailty, which I am unable to resist, impels me.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:21
verses.text: What will that teacher of righteousness say in reply to these things? How will he refute and convict a man who shall allege the frailty of the flesh as an excuse for his faults, unless he himself also shall be clothed with flesh, so that he may show that even the flesh is capable of virtue? For obstinacy cannot be refuted except by example.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:22
verses.text: For the things which you teach cannot have any weight unless you shall be the first to practice them; because the nature of men is inclined to faults, and wishes to sin not only with indulgence, but also with a reasonable plea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:23
verses.text: It is befitting that a master and teacher of virtue should most closely resemble man, that by overpowering sin he may teach man that sin may be overpowered by him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:24
verses.text: But if he is immortal, he can by no means propose an example to man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:25
verses.text: For there will stand forth some one persevering in his opinion, and will say: You indeed do not sin, because you are free from this body; you do not covet, because nothing is needed by an immortal; but I have need of many things for the support of this life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:26
verses.text: You do not fear death, because it can have no power against you.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:27
verses.text: You despise pain, because you can suffer no violence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:28
verses.text: But I, a mortal, fear both, because they bring upon me the severest tortures, which the weakness of the flesh cannot endure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:29
verses.text: A teacher of virtue therefore ought to have taken away this excuse from men, that no one may ascribe it to necessity that he sins, rather than to his own fault.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:30
verses.text: Therefore, that a teacher may be perfect, no objection ought to be brought forward by him who is to be taught, so that if he should happen to say, You enjoin impossibilities; the teacher may answer, See, I myself do them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:31
verses.text: But I am clothed with flesh, and it is the property of flesh to sin.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:32
verses.text: I too bear the same flesh, and yet sin does not bear rule in me.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:33
verses.text: It is difficult for me to despise riches, because otherwise I am unable to live in this body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:34
verses.text: See, I too have a body, and yet I contend against every desire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:35
verses.text: I am not able to bear pain or death for righteousness, because I am frail.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:36
verses.text: See, pain and death have power over me also; and I overcome those very things which you fear, that I may make you victorious over pain and death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:37
verses.text: I go before you through those things which you allege that it is impossible to endure: if you are not able to follow me giving directions, follow me going before you.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:38
verses.text: In this way all excuse is taken away, and you must confess that man is unjust through his own fault, since he does not follow a teacher of virtue, who is at the same time a guide.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:39
verses.text: You see, therefore, how much more perfect is a teacher who is mortal, because he is able to be a guide to one who is mortal, than one who is immortal, for he is unable to teach patient endurance who is not subject to passions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:40
verses.text: Nor, however, does this extend so far that I prefer man to God; but to show that man cannot be a perfect teacher unless he is also God, that he may by his heavenly authority impose upon men the necessity of obedience; nor God, unless he is clothed with a mortal body, that by carrying out his precepts to their completion in actions, he may bind others by the necessity of obedience.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:41
verses.text: It plainly therefore appears, that he who is a guide of life and teacher of righteousness must have a body, and that his teaching cannot otherwise be full and perfect, unless it has a root and foundation, and remains firm and fixed among men; and that he himself must undergo weakness of flesh and body, and display in himself the virtue of which he is a teacher, that he may teach it at the same time both by words and deeds.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 24:42
verses.text: Also, he must be subject to death and all sufferings, since the duties of virtue are occupied with the enduring of suffering, and the undergoing death; all which, as I have said, a perfect teacher ought to endure, that he may teach the possibility of their being endured.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 25:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 25:2
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book IV 25:3
